THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

MAY 7, 1902.

No. 15.

AN IMPORTANT PART OF COLLEGE EDUCATION.
EARS ago I heard a story of a young man, who, upon being asked about
the fare at his boarding house, answered, "Oh! it is good enough, what
there is of it!" And then, in reply to the further question, "What,
don't they give you enough?" said, "0 yes, there is plenty of it, such as it is."
I have been puzzling myself, from time to time ever since, as to whether the
Young man really meant anything or was merely trying to be considerate of his
landlady. On the whole, I have not come to any deep seated conviction as to
Whether the boarding house was or was not above reproach. Perhaps in this
case the young man was justified in giving an evasive answer; perhaps it was
as good a boarding house as he could afford and he did not wish to confess even
to himself that it was not all that he could desire; perhaps he thought it was
none of the other fellow's business. But it seems to me that there is altogether
too much of this being non committal; we are too fond of silencing ourselves
and others with "Well, it is not so had as it might be!" We take matters too
easily and put up with things which we all agree to be, to say the least, unsatwe
isfactory, and we do this because we are indifferent or because we are afraid
our
dly
Undoubte
ways.
may make enemies or do ourselves harm in other
neglect of duty comes principally from these two sources, indifference, and the
fear of consequences. These two sins are far more common with older than
with younger men. With the older ones they have become habits, and bad
habits are the most deadening things on earth; the things to be most carefully
guarded against by young men.
During college days is given, to those who have the great privilege of going
to college, the opportunity of cultivating, under the most favorable conditions,
their enthusiasm, and of overcoming their cowardice. They are not ridiculed
for their earnestness, and do not have any serious consequences to fear if they
Come out frankly with what they believe. Let them be enthusiastic and outspoken, for, while it is quite true that they are not yet ready to guide the affairs
of the nation, they are acquiring the power and forming traits of character which

T

e

will make them so.
The value of the experience of college life is by no means restricted to the
knowledge of facts and that far more important thing, the training of the mind,
Which makes it strong and fits it to undertake the problems which are sure to
come up for solution. There is another element, which we all recognize, but
Which is so near that we often overlook it; and this is the formation of character. In after life the struggle for supremacy, even for comfortable existence,
is so keen that even the best of men are in danger of being warped away from

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

their inmost convictions. It is hard for men to see that what seems to be
against their interests, especially when it brings up the question of comfort for
their wives and children, may he right and ought to receive their support.
During college life, questions of the same kind, but of less serious import, are
constantly arising; but there a man is not subjected to the same temptations as
when the happiness and welfare of all that is nearest and dearest to him seems
to be involved. It is easier for him to do what his conscience tells him is right;
he gets into the habit of looking upon questions without reference to .himself;
he sees the right and learns to choose it regardless of consequences, because the
consequences are comparatively unimportant. And when he has learned to do
this in matters pertaining to his life in college, he naturally and easily continues
the same method in the larger questions which confront him when he gets older
and goes out into the real world. Unfortunate, indeed, is he who neglects to
take advantage of this part of his college education. The young man who in
college descends to unworthy methods or who even looks with tolerance upon
anything which is unworthy—one who will say, as I have heard it said in
regard to some "dirty work" in a football game—"0, its all right so long as
the referee doesn't see it," or will tolerate a trainer who teaches tricks, just
because he is a good trainer; or who will resort to unfair means to get in or
keep out of some society any man, that young man is not only throwing away
a most important part of his education, but is abusing the years of his college
life to form a character which will make him distrusted, not only by his betters,
hut also by others of his own kind. My own personal experience when in college, and the experience which has come from being thrown into close contact
with college men and boys getting ready for college, teaches me that boys, and,
later, college men, are the most enthusiastically upright and honest men of the
world. I do not wish to be misunderstood in this statement. There are, of
course, hundreds and thousands more honest men in the world who are not college men than of those who are. But what I mean is, that one of the great
advantages of college education is that it, from its very character, teaches
uprightness, and that a man who has had this training is likely to be far better
in a truly moral way than he, individually, would have been without it.
Just as an athlete, who has had the benefit of proper training, is a far better
athlete than he would have been without it. So is the man better for the training which he gets from his teachers and from the association with his college
mates.
One thinks first, when speaking of college education, of the actual learning
and mental training there; nowadays, of the benefit which comes from physical
training and the participation in honest healthful sports. But, to my mind,
the training in strict honesty, in real manliness, is second to none of these.
Let, then, all college men do with more thought what the mass of them have
been doing so well, more or less unconsciously, teach themselves and their
mates the value of unbounding honesty, of uncompromising adherence to principle and the abhorrence of all which tends towards even toleration of anything
not absolutely worthy of a man and a gentleman.
"Disco at sompor vioturus;
Viva ut eras moriturus."

W. S. MARSTON.

Voice from room at end of corridor on third floor—"Look out, don't dare

On the following morning the following article appeared among the "Police Notes" of "The Globe:"
MYSTERIOUS PISTOL SHOT.

Excitement was caused last night, between 10 and 11 o'clock, by the report of firearms
in the corridor of a popular hotel in South Bethlehem. The order of events was as follows:
Commotion and loud talking; a pistol report; an exclamation, "0 my God!" silence;
appearance of hotel proprietor and police. The fracas was traced to a stranger who is here
for some sports today. No arrest was made. Why? There was an arrest recently for
using firearms on Broadway.

Needless to say, the lacrosse men were heroes to all the girls and terrors to
all the mothers in the hotel.

George A. Foster, of the Freshman class, who was called to his home in
Johnstown, Pa., on account of the death of his father, Mr. Andrew Foster, has
returned to the University.
The '03 "Hullaboloo" board has decided upon $1.25 as the price of its
book. Subscription agents will soon be on the trail.
The Hulla'baloo Club is making arrangements to hold another "smoker"
before the close of the year. The gathering will be held in the Trophy room.
By next fall the Board of Governors hopes to have permanent quarters in which
the club will begin its career as "The Senior Club."
As was announced in a recent issue of the NRWS--,T ETTER, the "senior week"
custom, which was founded by last year's class will be observed this year. The
programme for the week preceding commencement day consists of an excursion
down the bay, several entertainments in the city, a senior "Prom" and "Ivyplanting" at Homewood. Two committees have been appointed, the one on
arrangements consists of: H. B. Stone, S. Smith, P. Bernheim, J. C. Campbell, and I. R. Pells; the other consisting of T. C. Pinkerton, P. Bernheim,
R. S. Putts, and E. B. Beasley will see to the financial part.

THE COLLECTED PHYSICAL PAPERS OF DR. ROWLAND.
The Johns Hopkins Press has now in preparation a volume containing the
Physical Papers of the late Dr. Henry A. Rowland. The book which will contain between six and seven hundred pages will contain Professor Rowland's
articles and memoirs on physical subjects, together with all his popular writinks and addresses, numbering sixty in all, as well as the memorial address of
Professor Mendenhall, and a portrait of Dr. Rowland. The volume will be
issued under the editorial direction of a committee appointed for that purpose,
consisting of President Remsen, Professor Welch, and Professor Ames.

N illustrated talk on the Northfield Student Conference, with special
reference to the Hopkins' Camping Party, will be given in Levering
Hall, Friday next, May 9, at 5 P. M. A number of excellent stereopticon views will be shown. All are invited.

TO CHARLOTTE.
In after years, when recollections dear
Bring fresh again to Charlotte's mental view
Each form and face that once she met and knew,
Tho' some more clear than others may appear;
When of those many, scattered far and near,
She holds as dearest just a chosen few;
And chance acquaintance proves friend tried and true,
Whose heart's affeetion time nor place can veer;—
(Tho' then perhaps in some far distant land,)
May I be one of that blest chosen band
Whose image rests in Charlotte's sweet "mind's eye."—
Oh may her joys increase each year anew!
May she e'er prove herself as good and true
As now, when this is closed with fond good-bye.
J. A. A., '03.

HE BASEBALL TEAM plays Georgetown at American League Park this afternoon. This game is the first appearance of the team in Baltimore, and
offers also the first chance for Hopkins students to show a little material
appreciation of the ball-tossers, who both deserve and need a large amount of
such appreciation. For, in spite of its discouragements, obstacles, and reverses,
the baseball team of 1902 is a matter of pride to its members, its friends, and the
University. Its policy has been from the first to make dates with the best colleges available; it has stuck to this policy; and, above all, its officers and individual members have worked consistently and faithfully to develop the
material at hand. But fortune has turned her face. The Princeton game, which
was expected to put the management on a sound financial basis, fell on a rainy
day, and caused a heavy loss to the individual players, since the Athletic Association has delayed the recognition of the team in consideration of the sins of
some of its predecessors. At the Maryland Agricultural College game, described on another page, the boys were out for a victory. The score was: M.
A. C., 3; Hopkins, 2. Although it is the policy of the NEWS-L-ETTER to stand
aloof from athletic disagreements, we cannot ignore the complaints from many
sources that the Hopkins players were not treated with the courtesy which
should be extended by home men to a visiting team. On the other hand, the
position of Hopkins was within the definition of true sport. The Black and
Blue doesn't "quit,"—even under the provocation of a sorely trying game.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

7

The baseball team has played, it has played in hard luck, and it is not
Whining. Such conduct is called "sportsmanship." Let us hope that every
lover of college sport in the University will recognize this fact, and will present
himself this afternoon to cheer on the J. H. U. in an uphill game. Furthermore, there is a chance to see an exhibition of playing by Georgetown, perhaps
the strongest college team in America. Let not a man be missing when the
umpire calls "Play ball!"
HERE are two classes of students who never write for the NEWS-LETTER
—those who are afraid their efforts will not be accepted, and those who
are afraid that they will. These latter non.contributors feel that modesty
and good sense forbid their adding to the world's already large stock of poor
writing. Such a spirit, although commendable in some points, is tremendously
all unObstructive to the best interests of the paper. After all, the blame for
though
worthy matter in these pages falls to the lot of the editors,—unwilling
they be; and it is only by a plentiful supply of "copy" in general, and of expressions of opinion on matters of interest, that the paper can be representative.
This last applies likewise to the first class mentioned above—those who
grudge the chalice of losing time in productions foredoomed to oblivion and the
waste-basket. Such lack of spirit has often been belabored by the lash of criticism in these columns, and with some effect. An athletic analogy is applicable. The worker on a "scrub" team has little hope of appearing as an athletic hero; but his work does not go for nothing; he derives much personal
benefit from the exercise, and he may finally succeed in getting a place. So
with the individual student and the paper : you may not get a place, but you
are improving in a useful practice, you will certainly strike on something
the

HE ATHLETIC TEAMS sought laurels for the Black and Blue on the 26th
of last month. Only one—the Lacrosse—brought home the laurels; but
they all could boast of clean sport and a good struggle.
The lacrosse team keeps adding game after game to its long list of victories,
and indications seem to point to a season unmarred by a single defeat. The
secret of success, aside from the traditions of the game which the players seem
bound to uphold, lies in the fact that each player, varsity and scrub, looks upon
his work as a conscientious duty. Members of other teams could well afford to
take lessons in this respect from the lacrosse men. Every day track team
meet
candidates are hard at work at Electric Park getting in trim for the large
on the fourteenth of May. Hopkins stands an excellent chance to win a
majority of the points, if the men will only come out and work. The Pennsylvania games have become athletic history, and Hopkins returns home with
men
second place scored to her credit, resolved to do better next season. The
ran the good race that was expected of them; and but for .a slight accident in
getting one of the team started, the race would have closed with a more exciting
finish. The base ball team is spoken of in another column.

HU 1903 HULLABALOO is now under way; the measure of the success of its
career depends upon the students of the University, and especially the
undergraduates. The Board of Editors, no doubt, have sufficient confidence in themselves to undertake the writing of the whole book without assistance, but it is doubtful whether this would serve the best ends of the University.
For the book is intended to be a reflection—as bright as possible—of college
life at the J. H. U., and it can he this only with the co-operation of all those
concerned in the said college life. Descriptions of facetious clubs, class episodes
not called for in the curriculum, individual''grinds," and other localisms should
at once begin pouring in to the editor-in-chief, Box 374.

HE LEADING ARTICLE of this issue needs no commendation, and no introduction beyond the name of its author. As a gentleman who has had
exceptional opportunities for observing the influence of the secondary
school upon the college, and the problems that confront young college students,
no one could have more appreciative listeners than Mr. W. S. Marston when
he speaks of "An Important Part of College Education."

Dr. Remsen was among those who went from Baltimore to attend the Educational Conference held at Athens, Ga.
Among those who took a prominent part in the Eastern Public Education
Associations' conference, held last week in Levering Hall, under the auspices
of the Arundell Club was Dr. Joseph S. Ames. Many other prominent educators were present. Various subjects in connection with schools and education in general were discussed.
Dr. George B. Shattuck has returned from his trip to Florida and the
Bahama Islands. He has brought back with him many interesting specimens
of the characteristic geological formations of those regions. On May 15th, he
will visit the Dismal Swamp with his class in geology to study the fossil formations there.
Six members of the fourth year class of the Medical School have been appointed to positions in St. Luke's Hospital, New York, the German Hospital,
Brooklyn, and the Mount Sinai Hospital.
Dr. Harry L. Wilson, of the Latin Department, has now in press the
edition of Juvenal's Satires on which he has been engaged for several years
Past. The book, which will contain about four hundred pages, is in the hands
of a New York publisher and may be expected to appear early in 1903.
One of the most important recent appointments of llopkins men is that of
Dr. W. B. Huff, at present an instructor in the physical department, as associate in physics at Bryn Mawr College. Dr. Huff, whose work will begin next
fall, will have charge of the major course in physics and part of the graduate
work. It is worthy of note that Dr. Mackenzie, the professor of physics at
Bryn Mawr, is also a Hopkins man.
Dr. Huff graduated at the University of Wisconsin, and later received the
degree of master of arts at the University of Chicago. He came to the Hopkins
in 1897, and was made doctor of philosophy in 1900. Dr. Huff has always
been very popular with the students, and, while a graduate student was a good
athlete.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
RAISING MONEY FOR HOPKINS.

T the meeting held last Friday to try to secure money enough i to complete
the million dollar fund asked for, the committee was able to raise about
fifty thousand dollars. This leaves still about a quarter of a million
dollars to be secured. Encouraging speeches were made, and it is thought that
the meeting will bear more fruit than was evidenced at the time. Did Baltimoreans understand the reputation and prestige which the Johns Honkins
University gives to their city, there can not he a reasonable doubt but that the
amount asked for would have been subscribed long ago several times over.
Although the University is sadly in need of funds to carry on its work, yet the
impression which has gained ground of late years that the work of the University has been handicapped because of its straitened financial condition, is quite
erroneous. It was stated authoritatively at the meeting that neither the faculty
nor the scope of the laboratories had been impaired in any way by the University's financial difficulties.
Among those who subscribed to new amounts or to increases in former
donations were: Messrs. A. W. Machen, William Painter, John R. Bland, J.
W. Middendorf, Ernst Schmeisser, Louis Dohme, G. W. Gail, Hugh Bond, Jr.,
Frederick M. Colston, Harry Williams, Reuben Foster, W, H. Matthai, John
D. Howard, Dr. A. W. Halstead and Messrs. Strauss Brothers.

BASE BALL.
M. A. C., 3. HOPKINS, 2.
HE game of April 26th, at College Park, which went on record as a victory

t

for Maryland Agricultural College by a score of 3 to 2, was unsatisfactory
to both teams. That there were so many disputed points seemed to be
generally regretted. In the eighth inning, M. A. C. claimed to have scored a
man from third base before the third hand was put out by McKnight at second,
who caught Mathews' fly and then came in to make an unassisted double play
by touching Smith while off his base. The run was not allowed by the umpire.
Campbell, first up for Hopkins in the ninth, singled to right field. Hand
followed with a beautiful three-bagger down the line back of first base, which
was called foul after Campbell had run home and Hand himself reached third.
The hit was unquestionably good, except in the judgment of the umpire. Hand
tried over again and made a good single to right which put Campbell on third.
From there he scored the tieing run (score 2 to 2) on Ogle's neat sacrifice, but
on the play Hand, who had stolen second, was put out trying to reach home.
Had Hand's original hit been allowed more runs would have resulted and the
end perhaps been changed.
M. A. C. went to bat and succeeded in getting men on second and third
with two hands out. The base lines were crowded by a mob of yelling students.
The coacher by third base made a "fake" run to the plate, which, because of
the disorder and confusion, drew a quick throw from Whipple. The ball went
a little high and rolled some ten feet back of Campbell, who recovered it
Speedily, but meantime the true base runner had come in with the so-called
winning run. Thus, not by an honest manly effort, but by a very questionable

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

strategem, the game was secured by M. A. C. No such trick would have been
possible if the spectators had been kept within proper bounds.
Apart from these points of dispute, the contest was clean and fast. Both
pitchers did good work. Although Whipple allowed seven hits, these were well
scattered and perfect support would have brought him an easy shut-out. Hopkins' errors were not glaring and ghastly, but just little slips that marred an
otherwise excellent game. The team as a whole played with great credit, and
showed vast improvement over previous performances. Moore was again a
conspicuous factor in the game. The small score was chiefly due to the failure
to hit pitcher Brown, who had very little speed, but, what served better, admirable control. For M. A. C. Captain Nichols at shortstop played the star game.
The men lined up as follows:
Moore, s. s., Marine, c. f., McKnight, 1. f., Campbell, c., Hand, 2b., Ogle,
3b., Wright, r. f. Constantine, lb., Whipple, p.
During the past week the team has been out for batting and fielding
practice, and promises to play a consistently good game against Georgetown
today. No prediction is made as to the score, but Hopkins is expected to do all
that it is capable of. Great disappointment was manifested when early in the
season rain fell upon the day set for the game with Princeton. Manager Lazenby
has sought to make amends by bringing over the great famous nine from the
great Georgetown University. The contest is expected to attract interest not
only at Hopkins, but also throughout the city. Georgetown is perhaps the
strongest college team in America.
On saturday next, May 10th, Hopkins will go to Westminster to play the
last game of the season with Western Maryland College. As this is also the
day of the lacrosse game with Swarthmore, the contest in Westminster will
likely be played in the morning so that the base ball team may return to
Baltimore by afternoon. This arrangement will also permit any rooters who
desire it to witness both games.
The base ball team has experienced many set-backs during the season;
first, in having trouble to organize, and, then, in the prevalence of wet weather
and difficulty in securing practice grounds. Through it all the team has been
self- supporting, the men giving freely their time, money, and enthusiasm. The
results of their sacrifice will be more apparent after the game with Western
Maryland It is hoped, however, that their record and efforts will deserve
recognition by the Athletic Board.
HOPKINS 9, LEHIGH 1.

t

HE victory of our lacrosse team over Lehigh in the first of the championship games, on April 26, only adds stronger proof to the fact that our
prospects are exceptionally bright for another pennant on the walls of
the trophy room. Lehigh played at home, and the team which Hopkins
downed was one that could not possibly have been defeated by Hobart as it was
several weeks ago. Hopkins found them well trained, fairly well acquainted
with team play, and rough antagonists throughout.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

Hopkins started off at a rapid pace, and when five, then ten, minutes passed
Without scoring, it looked as though the game would be very close. Apparently
Hopkins was using this time in sizing up her opponents, for after twelve minutes' play the first goal was scored, and the six which followed before the end
of the half seemed to come with comparative ease. With a score of 7 to 0 to
our credit, Captain Schmeisser very wisely decided that it would be of no particular advantage to pile up a humiliating score in the second half. The players did not lie down by any means, but the aggressive play of the latter part of
the first half was not continued, and our defense was given abundant opportunities to demonstrate body checking, covering back, intercepting passes, and
numerous other "stunts," all of which they executed with the utmost dexterity.
Captain Schmeisser (lid not think of being excited over so much defense work,
and, with the able assistance of "Chick" and Henry Straus, managed to break
up all sorts of grand-stand plays which emanated from Captain Lattig's fertile
brain. Blanck and 'rough managed to make themselves as ubiquitous as newspaper men, and when the ball got through the entire defense, it generally took
a sudden halt before Briscoe's keen eye. He made several remarkably clever
stops, and Lehigh would not have scored at all had he not been a little overconfident of stopping the very shot which managed to get through.
With the exception of a little work now and then, the attack stood around
during this time and enjoyed the fun. When Lehigh scored about the middle
of the half, a slight restlessness was observed, and the result was a goal for
Hopkins within a minute. This, with one which was made at the beginning
of the half, brought the score up to 9 to 1 goals.
Hopkins lined up as follows: Putts, in home; B. Bernheim, out home;
Sayler, first attack; Bird, second attack; P. Bernheim, third attack; Abercrombie, center; Tough, third defense; Blanck, second defense; H. Straus, first
defense; E. Schmeisser, cover point; W. Schmeisser,(Captain) point; Briscoe,
goal.
Two thirty minute halves were played, and the men seemed to stand the
time extremely well. The team appears to be very well balanced, and with
hard, snappy work next Saturday afternoon, the championship should be ours.
Every man out to cheer the men to victory!

HE event in which we Hopkins men were most interested in at the Boys'
Latin School—Deichman's Dual meet, held last Friday at Electric Park,
was the invitation relay race run by the freshman and junior classes.
This was the last chance this year that freshman had to get some of the glory
they had lost in former contests with the upper classinen and they put forth
their best material in this race. Passagno and Enrich started. They ran even
uP to about 80 yards of the quarter, when Passagno pulled ahead. Tootle increased the lead and left Rosenheim fully forty yards behind at the finish.
Branham gained perceptibly on Nelson, and Hoffman started off but twenty-

Students at the Ohio Wesleyan University are trying to get together enough
men to form a glee club. This seems strange in a college so active in debating
and athletics.
The current issue of the College Mercury, College of the City of New York,
contains an excellent full page cut of this season's lacrosse team.
On Mr. F. Hopkinson Smith's recent visit to Ogontz, he was neariy taken
off his feet by a crowd of autograph "fiends,' who held him captive until his
signature had been obtained.
St. Mary's Chimes for April is devoted to Shakespeare and his plays. It
includes interesting articles on Shakespeare's burial place, his contructive
genius, his extant portraits, and his range of thought—the articles are enlivened by many excellent illustrations.
During the spring vacation the mining engineers of the tipper two classes
at Lafayette College went on an engineering trip through the western part of
the State.
The Yale Dramatic Association recently gave creditable performances of
Sheridan's ``The Critic" and Townely's "High Life Below Stairs."
At Princeton, amateur dramatics are taking the place of the musical clubs.
The glee club this year took no trip, while the Triangle Club, the dramatic organization, has numerous engagements, including dates at Pittsburgh and New
York. About 75 applicants are trying for the chorus alone.
Seldom does it happen that six different teams representing a university
are all successful on the same day; yet on April 19th Princeton's three baseball teams defeated their three opponents, the golf scored a victory, the Checker
Club defeated Yale, and Princeton scored the greatest number of points at its
annual handicap games.
Dr. George B. Germann, registrar of Columbia University, has prepared a
number of tables of statistics showing the relative rank of the principal American Universities, on the basis of student enrollment, based on the registration

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

of February 1st. The registration is as follows: Harvard, Columbia, Michigan, Chicago, California, Minnesota, Cornell, Wisconsin, Yale, Pennsylvania,
Northwestern, Indiana, Nebraska, Missouri, Princeton. Leland Stanford, Jr.,
Johns Hopkins. Judged from the standpoint of enrollment in the undergraduate body, Harvard leads, followed by California, Cornell, Yale, Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Columbia, Nebraska, Princeton, Leland Stanford, Jr.,
Chicago, Missouri, Pennsylvania, Northwestern, and Johns Hopkins.
No higher praise of the quality of Hopkins work could be asked than this
acknowledgement of its stand among the fourteen great institutions of the
country, in spite of the totally disproportionate number of its students.
Sometime ago the Missouri State University issued a bulletin giving facts
and figures about its growth during the past eleven years. It is gratifying to
note that the Johns Hopkins University is well represented in the faculty.
Naturally the greatest number are graduates of the Missouri State University;
having a representation of 22 in the faculty. Harvard ranks recond with 15,
Berlin third with 10, and the Johns Hopkins fourth with 8.
The University has an income of $420,655. The fees of students are small
since the State aims to make education practically free.

THE ELUSIVE BUTTON.
BY A LOSER

When a man goes off to college
He will ne'er "fly off the hooks"
If he gains one bit of knowledge
Which is not set down in books:
That the button, I infer,
Is a true barometer.
When one button has departed
He's left home about a week.
Trouble now has fairly started
And we do not need to speak
Of their leaving one by one,
Till the poor man is undone.
They can keep a man quite busy
When he lives away from home,
For it really makes him dizzy
If those buttons chance to roam;
If those buttons chance to stray
In an artless, aimless way.

A

"Nothing doing" he is crying
When his sad plight worst is felt.
What he cannot fix by tying
He can hold up with a belt.
One thing caution always dins---Safety lies in safety pins.

No. 15.

AN IMPORTANT PART OF COLLEGE EDUCATION.
EARS ago I heard a story of a young man, who, upon being asked about
the fare at his boarding house, answered, "Oh! it is good enough, what
there is of it!" And then, in reply to the further question, "What,
don't they give you enough?" said, "0 yes, there is plenty of it, such as it is."
I have been puzzling myself, from time to time ever since, as to whether the
Young man really meant anything or was merely trying to be considerate of his
landlady. On the whole, I have not come to any deep seated conviction as to
Whether the boarding house was or was not above reproach. Perhaps in this
case the young man was justified in giving an evasive answer; perhaps it was
as good a boarding house as he could afford and he did not wish to confess even
to himself that it was not all that he could desire; perhaps he thought it was
none of the other fellow's business. But it seems to me that there is altogether
too much of this being non committal; we are too fond of silencing ourselves
and others with "Well, it is not so had as it might be!" We take matters too
easily and put up with things which we all agree to be, to say the least, unsatwe
isfactory, and we do this because we are indifferent or because we are afraid
our
dly
Undoubte
ways.
may make enemies or do ourselves harm in other
neglect of duty comes principally from these two sources, indifference, and the
fear of consequences. These two sins are far more common with older than
with younger men. With the older ones they have become habits, and bad
habits are the most deadening things on earth; the things to be most carefully
guarded against by young men.
During college days is given, to those who have the great privilege of going
to college, the opportunity of cultivating, under the most favorable conditions,
their enthusiasm, and of overcoming their cowardice. They are not ridiculed
for their earnestness, and do not have any serious consequences to fear if they
Come out frankly with what they believe. Let them be enthusiastic and outspoken, for, while it is quite true that they are not yet ready to guide the affairs
of the nation, they are acquiring the power and forming traits of character which

T

e

will make them so.
The value of the experience of college life is by no means restricted to the
knowledge of facts and that far more important thing, the training of the mind,
Which makes it strong and fits it to undertake the problems which are sure to
come up for solution. There is another element, which we all recognize, but
Which is so near that we often overlook it; and this is the formation of character. In after life the struggle for supremacy, even for comfortable existence,
is so keen that even the best of men are in danger of being warped away from

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

their inmost convictions. It is hard for men to see that what seems to be
against their interests, especially when it brings up the question of comfort for
their wives and children, may he right and ought to receive their support.
During college life, questions of the same kind, but of less serious import, are
constantly arising; but there a man is not subjected to the same temptations as
when the happiness and welfare of all that is nearest and dearest to him seems
to be involved. It is easier for him to do what his conscience tells him is right;
he gets into the habit of looking upon questions without reference to .himself;
he sees the right and learns to choose it regardless of consequences, because the
consequences are comparatively unimportant. And when he has learned to do
this in matters pertaining to his life in college, he naturally and easily continues
the same method in the larger questions which confront him when he gets older
and goes out into the real world. Unfortunate, indeed, is he who neglects to
take advantage of this part of his college education. The young man who in
college descends to unworthy methods or who even looks with tolerance upon
anything which is unworthy—one who will say, as I have heard it said in
regard to some "dirty work" in a football game—"0, its all right so long as
the referee doesn't see it," or will tolerate a trainer who teaches tricks, just
because he is a good trainer; or who will resort to unfair means to get in or
keep out of some society any man, that young man is not only throwing away
a most important part of his education, but is abusing the years of his college
life to form a character which will make him distrusted, not only by his betters,
hut also by others of his own kind. My own personal experience when in college, and the experience which has come from being thrown into close contact
with college men and boys getting ready for college, teaches me that boys, and,
later, college men, are the most enthusiastically upright and honest men of the
world. I do not wish to be misunderstood in this statement. There are, of
course, hundreds and thousands more honest men in the world who are not college men than of those who are. But what I mean is, that one of the great
advantages of college education is that it, from its very character, teaches
uprightness, and that a man who has had this training is likely to be far better
in a truly moral way than he, individually, would have been without it.
Just as an athlete, who has had the benefit of proper training, is a far better
athlete than he would have been without it. So is the man better for the training which he gets from his teachers and from the association with his college
mates.
One thinks first, when speaking of college education, of the actual learning
and mental training there; nowadays, of the benefit which comes from physical
training and the participation in honest healthful sports. But, to my mind,
the training in strict honesty, in real manliness, is second to none of these.
Let, then, all college men do with more thought what the mass of them have
been doing so well, more or less unconsciously, teach themselves and their
mates the value of unbounding honesty, of uncompromising adherence to principle and the abhorrence of all which tends towards even toleration of anything
not absolutely worthy of a man and a gentleman.
"Disco at sompor vioturus;
Viva ut eras moriturus."

W. S. MARSTON.

On the following morning the following article appeared among the "Police Notes" of "The Globe:"
MYSTERIOUS PISTOL SHOT.

Excitement was caused last night, between 10 and 11 o'clock, by the report of firearms
in the corridor of a popular hotel in South Bethlehem. The order of events was as follows:
Commotion and loud talking; a pistol report; an exclamation, "0 my God!" silence;
appearance of hotel proprietor and police. The fracas was traced to a stranger who is here
for some sports today. No arrest was made. Why? There was an arrest recently for
using firearms on Broadway.

Needless to say, the lacrosse men were heroes to all the girls and terrors to
all the mothers in the hotel.

THE COLLECTED PHYSICAL PAPERS OF DR. ROWLAND.
The Johns Hopkins Press has now in preparation a volume containing the
Physical Papers of the late Dr. Henry A. Rowland. The book which will contain between six and seven hundred pages will contain Professor Rowland's
articles and memoirs on physical subjects, together with all his popular writinks and addresses, numbering sixty in all, as well as the memorial address of
Professor Mendenhall, and a portrait of Dr. Rowland. The volume will be
issued under the editorial direction of a committee appointed for that purpose,
consisting of President Remsen, Professor Welch, and Professor Ames.

TO CHARLOTTE.
In after years, when recollections dear
Bring fresh again to Charlotte's mental view
Each form and face that once she met and knew,
Tho' some more clear than others may appear;
When of those many, scattered far and near,
She holds as dearest just a chosen few;
And chance acquaintance proves friend tried and true,
Whose heart's affeetion time nor place can veer;—
(Tho' then perhaps in some far distant land,)
May I be one of that blest chosen band
Whose image rests in Charlotte's sweet "mind's eye."—
Oh may her joys increase each year anew!
May she e'er prove herself as good and true
As now, when this is closed with fond good-bye.
J. A. A., '03.

HE BASEBALL TEAM plays Georgetown at American League Park this afternoon. This game is the first appearance of the team in Baltimore, and
offers also the first chance for Hopkins students to show a little material
appreciation of the ball-tossers, who both deserve and need a large amount of
such appreciation. For, in spite of its discouragements, obstacles, and reverses,
the baseball team of 1902 is a matter of pride to its members, its friends, and the
University. Its policy has been from the first to make dates with the best colleges available; it has stuck to this policy; and, above all, its officers and individual members have worked consistently and faithfully to develop the
material at hand. But fortune has turned her face. The Princeton game, which
was expected to put the management on a sound financial basis, fell on a rainy
day, and caused a heavy loss to the individual players, since the Athletic Association has delayed the recognition of the team in consideration of the sins of
some of its predecessors. At the Maryland Agricultural College game, described on another page, the boys were out for a victory. The score was: M.
A. C., 3; Hopkins, 2. Although it is the policy of the NEWS-L-ETTER to stand
aloof from athletic disagreements, we cannot ignore the complaints from many
sources that the Hopkins players were not treated with the courtesy which
should be extended by home men to a visiting team. On the other hand, the
position of Hopkins was within the definition of true sport. The Black and
Blue doesn't "quit,"—even under the provocation of a sorely trying game.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

7

The baseball team has played, it has played in hard luck, and it is not
Whining. Such conduct is called "sportsmanship." Let us hope that every
lover of college sport in the University will recognize this fact, and will present
himself this afternoon to cheer on the J. H. U. in an uphill game. Furthermore, there is a chance to see an exhibition of playing by Georgetown, perhaps
the strongest college team in America. Let not a man be missing when the
umpire calls "Play ball!"
HERE are two classes of students who never write for the NEWS-LETTER
—those who are afraid their efforts will not be accepted, and those who
are afraid that they will. These latter non.contributors feel that modesty
and good sense forbid their adding to the world's already large stock of poor
writing. Such a spirit, although commendable in some points, is tremendously
all unObstructive to the best interests of the paper. After all, the blame for
though
worthy matter in these pages falls to the lot of the editors,—unwilling
they be; and it is only by a plentiful supply of "copy" in general, and of expressions of opinion on matters of interest, that the paper can be representative.
This last applies likewise to the first class mentioned above—those who
grudge the chalice of losing time in productions foredoomed to oblivion and the
waste-basket. Such lack of spirit has often been belabored by the lash of criticism in these columns, and with some effect. An athletic analogy is applicable. The worker on a "scrub" team has little hope of appearing as an athletic hero; but his work does not go for nothing; he derives much personal

HE ATHLETIC TEAMS sought laurels for the Black and Blue on the 26th
of last month. Only one—the Lacrosse—brought home the laurels; but
they all could boast of clean sport and a good struggle.
The lacrosse team keeps adding game after game to its long list of victories,
and indications seem to point to a season unmarred by a single defeat. The
secret of success, aside from the traditions of the game which the players seem
bound to uphold, lies in the fact that each player, varsity and scrub, looks upon
his work as a conscientious duty. Members of other teams could well afford to
take lessons in this respect from the lacrosse men. Every day track team
meet
candidates are hard at work at Electric Park getting in trim for the large
on the fourteenth of May. Hopkins stands an excellent chance to win a
majority of the points, if the men will only come out and work. The Pennsylvania games have become athletic history, and Hopkins returns home with
men
second place scored to her credit, resolved to do better next season. The
ran the good race that was expected of them; and but for .a slight accident in
getting one of the team started, the race would have closed with a more exciting
finish. The base ball team is spoken of in another column.

HU 1903 HULLABALOO is now under way; the measure of the success of its
career depends upon the students of the University, and especially the
undergraduates. The Board of Editors, no doubt, have sufficient confidence in themselves to undertake the writing of the whole book without assistance, but it is doubtful whether this would serve the best ends of the University.

not called for in the curriculum, individual''grinds," and other localisms should
at once begin pouring in to the editor-in-chief, Box 374.

Dr. Remsen was among those who went from Baltimore to attend the Educational Conference held at Athens, Ga.
Among those who took a prominent part in the Eastern Public Education
Associations' conference, held last week in Levering Hall, under the auspices
of the Arundell Club was Dr. Joseph S. Ames. Many other prominent educators were present. Various subjects in connection with schools and education in general were discussed.
Dr. George B. Shattuck has returned from his trip to Florida and the
Bahama Islands. He has brought back with him many interesting specimens
of the characteristic geological formations of those regions. On May 15th, he
will visit the Dismal Swamp with his class in geology to study the fossil formations there.
Six members of the fourth year class of the Medical School have been appointed to positions in St. Luke's Hospital, New York, the German Hospital,
Brooklyn, and the Mount Sinai Hospital.
Dr. Harry L. Wilson, of the Latin Department, has now in press the
edition of Juvenal's Satires on which he has been engaged for several years
Past. The book, which will contain about four hundred pages, is in the hands
of a New York publisher and may be expected to appear early in 1903.
One of the most important recent appointments of llopkins men is that of
Dr. W. B. Huff, at present an instructor in the physical department, as associate in physics at Bryn Mawr College. Dr. Huff, whose work will begin next
fall, will have charge of the major course in physics and part of the graduate
work. It is worthy of note that Dr. Mackenzie, the professor of physics at
Bryn Mawr, is also a Hopkins man.
Dr. Huff graduated at the University of Wisconsin, and later received the
degree of master of arts at the University of Chicago. He came to the Hopkins
in 1897, and was made doctor of philosophy in 1900. Dr. Huff has always
been very popular with the students, and, while a graduate student was a good
athlete.

RAISING MONEY FOR HOPKINS.

T the meeting held last Friday to try to secure money enough i to complete
the million dollar fund asked for, the committee was able to raise about
fifty thousand dollars. This leaves still about a quarter of a million
dollars to be secured. Encouraging speeches were made, and it is thought that
the meeting will bear more fruit than was evidenced at the time. Did Baltimoreans understand the reputation and prestige which the Johns Honkins
University gives to their city, there can not he a reasonable doubt but that the
amount asked for would have been subscribed long ago several times over.
Although the University is sadly in need of funds to carry on its work, yet the
impression which has gained ground of late years that the work of the University has been handicapped because of its straitened financial condition, is quite
erroneous. It was stated authoritatively at the meeting that neither the faculty
nor the scope of the laboratories had been impaired in any way by the University's financial difficulties.
Among those who subscribed to new amounts or to increases in former
donations were: Messrs. A. W. Machen, William Painter, John R. Bland, J.
W. Middendorf, Ernst Schmeisser, Louis Dohme, G. W. Gail, Hugh Bond, Jr.,
Frederick M. Colston, Harry Williams, Reuben Foster, W, H. Matthai, John
D. Howard, Dr. A. W. Halstead and Messrs. Strauss Brothers.

HE game of April 26th, at College Park, which went on record as a victory

t

for Maryland Agricultural College by a score of 3 to 2, was unsatisfactory
to both teams. That there were so many disputed points seemed to be
generally regretted. In the eighth inning, M. A. C. claimed to have scored a
man from third base before the third hand was put out by McKnight at second,
who caught Mathews' fly and then came in to make an unassisted double play
by touching Smith while off his base. The run was not allowed by the umpire.
Campbell, first up for Hopkins in the ninth, singled to right field. Hand
followed with a beautiful three-bagger down the line back of first base, which
was called foul after Campbell had run home and Hand himself reached third.
The hit was unquestionably good, except in the judgment of the umpire. Hand
tried over again and made a good single to right which put Campbell on third.
From there he scored the tieing run (score 2 to 2) on Ogle's neat sacrifice, but
on the play Hand, who had stolen second, was put out trying to reach home.
Had Hand's original hit been allowed more runs would have resulted and the
end perhaps been changed.
M. A. C. went to bat and succeeded in getting men on second and third
with two hands out. The base lines were crowded by a mob of yelling students.
The coacher by third base made a "fake" run to the plate, which, because of
the disorder and confusion, drew a quick throw from Whipple. The ball went
a little high and rolled some ten feet back of Campbell, who recovered it
Speedily, but meantime the true base runner had come in with the so-called
winning run. Thus, not by an honest manly effort, but by a very questionable

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

strategem, the game was secured by M. A. C. No such trick would have been
possible if the spectators had been kept within proper bounds.
Apart from these points of dispute, the contest was clean and fast. Both
pitchers did good work. Although Whipple allowed seven hits, these were well
scattered and perfect support would have brought him an easy shut-out. Hopkins' errors were not glaring and ghastly, but just little slips that marred an
otherwise excellent game. The team as a whole played with great credit, and
showed vast improvement over previous performances. Moore was again a
conspicuous factor in the game. The small score was chiefly due to the failure
to hit pitcher Brown, who had very little speed, but, what served better, admirable control. For M. A. C. Captain Nichols at shortstop played the star game.
The men lined up as follows:
Moore, s. s., Marine, c. f., McKnight, 1. f., Campbell, c., Hand, 2b., Ogle,
3b., Wright, r. f. Constantine, lb., Whipple, p.
During the past week the team has been out for batting and fielding
practice, and promises to play a consistently good game against Georgetown
today. No prediction is made as to the score, but Hopkins is expected to do all
that it is capable of. Great disappointment was manifested when early in the
season rain fell upon the day set for the game with Princeton. Manager Lazenby
has sought to make amends by bringing over the great famous nine from the
great Georgetown University. The contest is expected to attract interest not
only at Hopkins, but also throughout the city. Georgetown is perhaps the
strongest college team in America.
On saturday next, May 10th, Hopkins will go to Westminster to play the
last game of the season with Western Maryland College. As this is also the
day of the lacrosse game with Swarthmore, the contest in Westminster will
likely be played in the morning so that the base ball team may return to
Baltimore by afternoon. This arrangement will also permit any rooters who
desire it to witness both games.
The base ball team has experienced many set-backs during the season;
first, in having trouble to organize, and, then, in the prevalence of wet weather
and difficulty in securing practice grounds. Through it all the team has been
self- supporting, the men giving freely their time, money, and enthusiasm. The
results of their sacrifice will be more apparent after the game with Western
Maryland It is hoped, however, that their record and efforts will deserve
recognition by the Athletic Board.
HOPKINS 9, LEHIGH 1.

t

HE victory of our lacrosse team over Lehigh in the first of the championship games, on April 26, only adds stronger proof to the fact that our
prospects are exceptionally bright for another pennant on the walls of
the trophy room. Lehigh played at home, and the team which Hopkins
downed was one that could not possibly have been defeated by Hobart as it was
several weeks ago. Hopkins found them well trained, fairly well acquainted
with team play, and rough antagonists throughout.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

Hopkins started off at a rapid pace, and when five, then ten, minutes passed
Without scoring, it looked as though the game would be very close. Apparently
Hopkins was using this time in sizing up her opponents, for after twelve minutes' play the first goal was scored, and the six which followed before the end
of the half seemed to come with comparative ease. With a score of 7 to 0 to
our credit, Captain Schmeisser very wisely decided that it would be of no particular advantage to pile up a humiliating score in the second half. The players did not lie down by any means, but the aggressive play of the latter part of
the first half was not continued, and our defense was given abundant opportunities to demonstrate body checking, covering back, intercepting passes, and
numerous other "stunts," all of which they executed with the utmost dexterity.
Captain Schmeisser (lid not think of being excited over so much defense work,
and, with the able assistance of "Chick" and Henry Straus, managed to break
up all sorts of grand-stand plays which emanated from Captain Lattig's fertile
brain. Blanck and 'rough managed to make themselves as ubiquitous as newspaper men, and when the ball got through the entire defense, it generally took
a sudden halt before Briscoe's keen eye. He made several remarkably clever
stops, and Lehigh would not have scored at all had he not been a little overconfident of stopping the very shot which managed to get through.
With the exception of a little work now and then, the attack stood around
during this time and enjoyed the fun. When Lehigh scored about the middle
of the half, a slight restlessness was observed, and the result was a goal for
Hopkins within a minute. This, with one which was made at the beginning
of the half, brought the score up to 9 to 1 goals.
Hopkins lined up as follows: Putts, in home; B. Bernheim, out home;
Sayler, first attack; Bird, second attack; P. Bernheim, third attack; Abercrombie, center; Tough, third defense; Blanck, second defense; H. Straus, first
defense; E. Schmeisser, cover point; W. Schmeisser,(Captain) point; Briscoe,
goal.
Two thirty minute halves were played, and the men seemed to stand the
time extremely well. The team appears to be very well balanced, and with
hard, snappy work next Saturday afternoon, the championship should be ours.
Every man out to cheer the men to victory!

03' WINS AGAIN.
HE event in which we Hopkins men were most interested in at the Boys'
Latin School—Deichman's Dual meet, held last Friday at Electric Park,
was the invitation relay race run by the freshman and junior classes.
This was the last chance this year that freshman had to get some of the glory
they had lost in former contests with the upper classinen and they put forth
their best material in this race. Passagno and Enrich started. They ran even
uP to about 80 yards of the quarter, when Passagno pulled ahead. Tootle increased the lead and left Rosenheim fully forty yards behind at the finish.
Branham gained perceptibly on Nelson, and Hoffman started off but twenty-

t;

14

THE NEWS—LETTER.

five yards ahead of Le Cron, who held his own and Hoffman finished with the
lead with which he started. Time, 3-43i. Tootle and Hoffman ran in the fast
time of 531 seconds.

AMONG THE COLLEGES.
OR the Yale-Harvard debate, May 12, the question decided upon is:
"Resolved, That the immigration of Chinese laborers to our insular
possessions should be prohibited by law."

5

Students at the Ohio Wesleyan University are trying to get together enough
men to form a glee club. This seems strange in a college so active in debating
and athletics.
The current issue of the College Mercury, College of the City of New York,
contains an excellent full page cut of this season's lacrosse team.
On Mr. F. Hopkinson Smith's recent visit to Ogontz, he was neariy taken
off his feet by a crowd of autograph "fiends,' who held him captive until his
signature had been obtained.
St. Mary's Chimes for April is devoted to Shakespeare and his plays. It
includes interesting articles on Shakespeare's burial place, his contructive
genius, his extant portraits, and his range of thought—the articles are enlivened by many excellent illustrations.
During the spring vacation the mining engineers of the tipper two classes
at Lafayette College went on an engineering trip through the western part of
the State.
The Yale Dramatic Association recently gave creditable performances of
Sheridan's ``The Critic" and Townely's "High Life Below Stairs."
At Princeton, amateur dramatics are taking the place of the musical clubs.
The glee club this year took no trip, while the Triangle Club, the dramatic organization, has numerous engagements, including dates at Pittsburgh and New
York. About 75 applicants are trying for the chorus alone.
Seldom does it happen that six different teams representing a university
are all successful on the same day; yet on April 19th Princeton's three baseball teams defeated their three opponents, the golf scored a victory, the Checker
Club defeated Yale, and Princeton scored the greatest number of points at its
annual handicap games.
Dr. George B. Germann, registrar of Columbia University, has prepared a
number of tables of statistics showing the relative rank of the principal American Universities, on the basis of student enrollment, based on the registration

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

of February 1st. The registration is as follows: Harvard, Columbia, Michigan, Chicago, California, Minnesota, Cornell, Wisconsin, Yale, Pennsylvania,
Northwestern, Indiana, Nebraska, Missouri, Princeton. Leland Stanford, Jr.,
Johns Hopkins. Judged from the standpoint of enrollment in the undergraduate body, Harvard leads, followed by California, Cornell, Yale, Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Columbia, Nebraska, Princeton, Leland Stanford, Jr.,
Chicago, Missouri, Pennsylvania, Northwestern, and Johns Hopkins.
No higher praise of the quality of Hopkins work could be asked than this
acknowledgement of its stand among the fourteen great institutions of the
country, in spite of the totally disproportionate number of its students.
Sometime ago the Missouri State University issued a bulletin giving facts
and figures about its growth during the past eleven years. It is gratifying to
note that the Johns Hopkins University is well represented in the faculty.
Naturally the greatest number are graduates of the Missouri State University;
having a representation of 22 in the faculty. Harvard ranks recond with 15,
Berlin third with 10, and the Johns Hopkins fourth with 8.
The University has an income of $420,655. The fees of students are small
since the State aims to make education practically free.

THE ELUSIVE BUTTON.
BY A LOSER

When a man goes off to college
He will ne'er "fly off the hooks"
If he gains one bit of knowledge
Which is not set down in books:
That the button, I infer,
Is a true barometer.
When one button has departed
He's left home about a week.
Trouble now has fairly started
And we do not need to speak
Of their leaving one by one,
Till the poor man is undone.
They can keep a man quite busy
When he lives away from home,
For it really makes him dizzy
If those buttons chance to roam;
If those buttons chance to stray
In an artless, aimless way.

A

"Nothing doing" he is crying
When his sad plight worst is felt.
What he cannot fix by tying
He can hold up with a belt.
One thing caution always dins---Safety lies in safety pins.
